Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Situation2: They have been scheduled to chant a portion during the service.
Story:
I stared at my phone, rereading the text from Ethan: “Can’t wait for our night together. Just us.” My heart fluttered. We’d barely seen each other all week, and tomorrow he’d be gone for work. Tonight was our only chance. But then I glanced at my calendar and felt my stomach twist. I was scheduled to chant Torah at synagogue tonight—a commitment I’d made months ago. My rabbi had even called to remind me how meaningful it was to the community, especially since I’d been practicing for weeks.

Ethan expected a cozy evening, maybe dinner and a movie, just the two of us. But my community expected me to show up, to honor my promise and my faith. I could almost hear my mother’s voice: “It’s important to keep your word, especially to your community.” I wanted to be the girlfriend Ethan deserved, present and loving, but I also wanted to be the Jew my family and synagogue could count on. The two parts of me pulled in opposite directions, and I felt the pressure mounting, my chest tight with worry as I tried to figure out what to do.
